IMiC supplementary material Chapter 1 Supplementary Material for IMiC Intervention Effects Manuscript 1.1 Organization of the Online Supplement

IMiC supplementary material Chapter 1 Supplementary Material for IMiC Intervention Effects Manuscript This online supplementary appendix provides the complete analytical outputs supporting the manuscript The impact of nutritional interventions on human milk in low resource settings: findings from the International Milk Composition (IMiC) Consortium. 1.1 Organization of the Online Supplement 1.1.1 Study Baseline Characteristics Detailed maternal, infant, and household characteristics for the IMiC subsamples across trials, including comparisons with parent trial populations and baseline balance across intervention arms. 1.1.2 Human Milk Component Distributions Unadjusted distributions of all measured human milk components, including macronutrients, micronutrients, B-vitamins, HMOs, targeted metabolites, proteins, and microbiome features, stratified by study and visit where applicable. 1.1.3 Adjusted Intervention Effects on Individual Milk Components Covariate-adjusted average treatment effect estimates for primary outcomes (macronutrients and micronutrients), with false-discovery rate correction applied by outcome group. 1.1.4 Unadjusted Intervention Effects on Individual Milk Components Corresponding unadjusted estimates for all milk components. 1.1.5 Unscaled Intervention Effects on Individual Milk Components Corresponding adjusted, but unscaled estimates for all milk components, using the raw concentration values without Z-scoring for comparison across milk components. 1.1.6 Targeted and Exploratory Milk Components Results for tertiary and exploratory outcomes, including targeted metabolomics, untargeted metabolomics, untargeted proteomics, and milk microbiome analyses, with pathway- and set-level summaries. 1.1.7 Subgroup analyses stratified by maternal BMI Effect modification analyses stratified by maternal BMI category (underweight vs not) 1.1.8 Trajectory analyses of human milk component change across lactation Visualization of longitudinal trajectories of selected milk components across lactation by study and intervention arm.

Chapter 2 Study Baseline Characteristics 2.1 Misame 2.2 Mumta 2.3 Elicit
desc_stats.html
Chapter 3 Human Milk Component Distributions 3.1 Histograms of milk components 3.2 Interactive boxplots

Chapter 3 Human Milk Component Distributions This chapter presents descriptive summaries of human milk composition across studies, visits, and randomized intervention arms. The purpose of these analyses is to characterize the empirical distributions of milk components prior to modeling intervention effects and to provide context for the magnitude, variability, and baseline heterogeneity of milk constituents across settings. Interactive density plots and boxplots are provided for all measured milk components, including macronutrients, micronutrients, B-vitamins, human milk oligosaccharides, targeted metabolites, and other analytes defined in the IMiC outcome framework. Distributions are stratified by study, milk collection visit, and intervention arm, allowing visualization of between-site differences, within-site variability, and potential shifts in central tendency or dispersion associated with supplementation. These figures are descriptive only. No covariate adjustment, hypothesis testing, or multiple-comparison correction is applied in this chapter. Apparent differences between arms or visits should therefore be interpreted as exploratory and may reflect baseline differences, sampling variability, or physiological variation across lactation, rather than causal intervention effects. Formal estimates of intervention effects are presented in subsequent chapters using prespecified statistical models. 3.1 Histograms of milk components Unstratified histograms of milk component distributions. Use the dropdown menu to select the milk component of interest. 3.2 Interactive boxplots Boxplots faceted by site and stratified by intervention arm and visit for all milk components. Use the dropdown menu to select the milk component of interest.
adjusted-intervention-effects-on-individual-milk-components-1.html
Chapter 4 Adjusted Intervention Effects on Individual Milk Components 4.1 Primary Outcomes: Macronutrients and Micronutrients

Chapter 4 Adjusted Intervention Effects on Individual Milk Components This chapter presents covariate-adjusted estimates of the effects of maternal nutritional interventions on individual human milk components. Results are shown as forest plots and accompanying tables, stratified by study and milk collection visit. Average treatment effects (ATEs) are estimated using targeted maximum likelihood estimation (TMLE) with adjustment for prespecified baseline prognostic factors. False-discovery rate (FDR) correction is applied within outcome groups. For each milk modality, the intervention effects are shown in forest plots, faceted by study and visit. Significant effects after FDR correction are shown with solid circles. Intervention average treatment effects are first shown for combined intervention arms (pooling post-natal nutritional intervention arms), and then the effects are shown contrasting each randomized arm against the control arms. Effects are estimated using TMLE, adjusting for baseline prognistic factors. Tables of results are shown below each forest plot, which also include unscaled estimates (in original units of measurement). 4.1 Primary Outcomes: Macronutrients and Micronutrients Forest plots display point estimates and 95% confidence intervals for standardized effect sizes. Solid symbols indicate effects that remain statistically significant after FDR correction within the corresponding outcome group. Dashed vertical lines denote the null effect. 4.1.0.1 Macronutrients - combined arms 4.1.0.2 Macronutrients - stratified arms 4.1.0.3 Micronutrients - combined arms Includes fat-soluble vitamins 4.1.0.4 Micronutrients - stratified arms 4.1.0.5 B-vitamins - combined arms 4.1.0.6 B-vitamins - stratified arms 4.1.0.7 HMOs - combined arms 4.1.0.8 HMOs - stratified arms 4.1.0.9 Bioactives - combined arms 4.1.0.10 Bioactives - stratified arms
unadjusted-intervention-effects-on-individual-milk-components-1.html
Chapter 5 Unadjusted Intervention Effects on Individual Milk Components

Chapter 5 Unadjusted Intervention Effects on Individual Milk Components This chapter presents unadjusted estimates of the effects of maternal nutritional interventions on individual human milk components. Results are shown as forest plots stratified by study and milk collection visit and are intended to provide descriptive comparisons with the covariate-adjusted analyses presented in the preceding chapter. Average treatment effects (ATEs) are estimated using targeted maximum likelihood estimation (TMLE) without adjustment for baseline prognostic factors. As in the adjusted analyses, results are first presented for pooled postnatal nutritional intervention arms to improve precision, followed by estimates for each randomized intervention arm contrasted with the corresponding control arm. False-discovery rate (FDR) correction is applied within outcome groups, and effects remaining significant after correction are indicated by solid symbols in the forest plots. These unadjusted results should be interpreted as descriptive. Differences between unadjusted and adjusted estimates may reflect confounding by baseline maternal, infant, or household characteristics, differences in sampling structure across studies and visits, or chance variation. Formal inference and primary interpretation of intervention effects are based on the covariate-adjusted analyses presented elsewhere in the supplement. 5.0.0.1 Macronutrients - combined arms 5.0.0.2 Macronutrients - stratified arms 5.0.0.3 Micronutrients - combined arms 5.0.0.4 Micronutrients - stratified arms 5.0.0.5 B-vitamins - combined arms 5.0.0.6 B-vitamins - stratified arms 5.0.0.7 HMOs - combined arms 5.0.0.8 HMOs - stratified arms 5.0.0.9 Bioactives - combined arms 5.0.0.10 Bioactives - stratified arms
unscaled-intervention-effects-on-individual-milk-components-1.html
Chapter 6 Unscaled Intervention Effects on Individual Milk Components

Chapter 6 Unscaled Intervention Effects on Individual Milk Components This chapter presents intervention effect estimates for individual human milk components expressed in their original units of measurement. Results are shown as forest plots stratified by study and milk collection visit and are intended to facilitate clinical and biological interpretation of effect magnitudes. Average treatment effects (ATEs) are estimated using targeted maximum likelihood estimation (TMLE) and are displayed on the natural scale of each milk component (for example, g/100 mL, mg/L, or µg/L, depending on the analyte). As in other chapters, results are first presented for pooled postnatal nutritional intervention arms to improve precision, followed by estimates for each randomized intervention arm contrasted with the corresponding control arm. False-discovery rate (FDR) correction is applied within outcome groups, and effects remaining significant after correction are indicated by solid symbols in the forest plots. Because milk components differ substantially in scale and variability, these unscaled plots are not intended for cross-component comparison. Instead, they complement the standardized analyses by providing interpretable estimates of absolute change in milk composition attributable to intervention exposure. Primary inference regarding the presence and consistency of intervention effects is based on the standardized, covariate-adjusted analyses presented in earlier chapters, while this chapter supports contextualization of those findings in biologically meaningful units. 6.0.0.1 Macronutrients - combined arms ## Adding missing grouping variables: `measure` 6.0.0.2 Macronutrients - stratified arms ## Adding missing grouping variables: `measure` 6.0.0.3 Micronutrients - combined arms ## Adding missing grouping variables: `measure` 6.0.0.4 Micronutrients - stratified arms 6.0.0.5 B-vitamins - combined arms ## Adding missing grouping variables: `measure` 6.0.0.6 B-vitamins - stratified arms 6.0.0.7 HMOs - combined arms ## Adding missing grouping variables: `measure` 6.0.0.8 HMOs - stratified arms 6.0.0.9 Bioactives - combined arms ## Adding missing grouping variables: `measure` 6.0.0.10 Bioactives - stratified arms
exploratory-outcomes-microbiome-proteomics-and-untargeted-metabolomics.html
Chapter 7 Exploratory Outcomes: Microbiome, Proteomics, and Untargeted Metabolomics 7.1 Microbiome 7.2 Proteomics 7.3 Untargeted Metabolomics

Chapter 7 Exploratory Outcomes: Microbiome, Proteomics, and Untargeted Metabolomics This chapter presents exploratory analyses of human milk components that were not designated as primary or secondary outcomes, including the milk microbiome, untargeted proteomics, and untargeted metabolomics. These analyses are intended to provide a comprehensive view of potential intervention-related signals across high-dimensional data modalities and to support hypothesis generation. All results in this chapter should be interpreted cautiously. Estimates are subject to substantial multiple-testing burden, variable measurement error, and, in some cases, limited sample size or incomplete intervention contrasts. Formal inference and primary conclusions are therefore based on prespecified outcomes presented in earlier chapters. 7.1 Microbiome 7.1.1 Intervention effects on microbiome diversity This section summarizes intervention effects on milk microbiome alpha diversity metrics. Forest plots display average treatment effect estimates for standard diversity measures, stratified by study and milk collection visit. Results are shown first for pooled postnatal nutritional intervention arms, followed by arm-stratified contrasts against the control condition. Across studies and visits, no consistent intervention-related changes in microbiome diversity were observed. The magnitude and direction of estimated effects varied across time points and studies, and confidence intervals generally overlapped the null, consistent with limited sensitivity of milk microbiome diversity to maternal nutritional supplementation. 7.1.1.1 Combined arms: 7.1.1.2 Stratified arms: 7.1.2 Intervention effects on individual microbial features Volcano plots summarize intervention effects on individual microbial taxa and sequence variants. Results are shown for pooled intervention arms and for arm-stratified contrasts. Across analyses, the distribution of effect estimates and p-values was consistent with a global null hypothesis, with no enrichment of statistically significant features beyond what would be expected by chance after accounting for multiple testing. No taxa exhibited reproducible intervention-associated shifts across studies or visits. 7.1.2.1 Combined arms: 7.1.2.2 Stratified arms: 7.2 Proteomics Untargeted proteomic analyses were conducted in a subset of motherinfant dyads and were subject to important design constraints. Proteomics data were available for a limited number of samples and, in the ELICIT trial, were collected only in the control arm. As a result, formal estimation of randomized intervention effects was not possible for this modality. Volcano plots are presented for completeness and descriptive purposes only. Across both pooled and arm-stratified visualizations, the proportion of nominally significant protein-level associations was consistent with false positives expected under a global null distribution. No coherent pattern of protein-level changes attributable to intervention exposure was observed. 7.2.0.1 Combined-arms 7.2.0.2 Arm-stratified 7.3 Untargeted Metabolomics This section summarizes exploratory intervention effects on untargeted milk metabolites. Volcano plots display effect estimates and significance levels for thousands of metabolite features, aggregated across studies and visits. Compared with the microbiome and proteomics analyses, untargeted metabolomics exhibited a higher density of features with nominal evidence of intervention association. However, signals were heterogeneous across studies and time points, and only a small fraction of features remained significant after correction for multiple testing. These results indicate the presence of weak, distributed metabolic shifts rather than large, discrete intervention effects on individual metabolites. Pathway-level summaries and targeted metabolite analyses, which provide a more interpretable and biologically coherent view of metabolic changes, are presented elsewhere in the supplement and in the main manuscript.
subgroup-analyses-stratified-by-maternal-bmi-1.html
Chapter 8 Subgroup analyses stratified by maternal BMI

Chapter 8 Subgroup analyses stratified by maternal BMI This chapter presents subgroup analyses evaluating whether the effects of maternal nutritional interventions on human milk components differed by maternal nutritional status at baseline, operationalized using maternal body mass index (BMI). Maternal BMI was dichotomized a priori into underweight (BMI  18.5 kg/m²) and normal or overweight (BMI > 18.5 kg/m²) categories, consistent with international definitions and the distribution of BMI across studies. Analyses were conducted separately within each BMI stratum using the same targeted maximum likelihood estimation (TMLE) framework as in the primary adjusted analyses, including adjustment for prespecified baseline prognostic covariates and standardization of outcomes. Average treatment effects were estimated within strata for primary outcomes (macronutrients, micronutrients, and B-vitamins), secondary outcomes (HMOs and bioactive proteins), and tertiary outcomes (targeted metabolites). To formally assess effect heterogeneity, interaction p-values were computed for each milk component by comparing stratum-specific treatment effect estimates. Specifically, differences in estimated average treatment effects between BMI strata were evaluated using a Wald-type test based on the difference in estimates scaled by the pooled standard error. These interaction p-values are reported alongside stratum-specific estimates to facilitate assessment of potential effect modification. Forest plots summarize BMI-stratified treatment effects for selected outcome groups, and accompanying tables report point estimates, confidence intervals, and interaction p-values for all analyzed components. Across studies, visits, and outcome domains, there was no consistent evidence of effect modification by maternal BMI. Where stratum-specific estimates differed in magnitude or direction, confidence intervals were typically wide and interaction tests were not statistically significant after accounting for multiplicity and limited subgroup sample sizes. These subgroup analyses were conducted as secondary, exploratory assessments of heterogeneity and were not powered to detect modest interaction effects. Consequently, they should be interpreted cautiously. Primary inference regarding intervention effects is based on pooled analyses presented in earlier chapters, with BMI-stratified results serving to assess robustness of findings across maternal nutritional status categories and to inform future hypothesis generation rather than definitive conclusions about effect modification.
trajectory-analyses-of-human-milk-component-change-across-lactation-1.html
Chapter 9 Trajectory analyses of human milk component change across lactation 9.1 Tables 9.2 Trajectory lineplots

Chapter 9 Trajectory analyses of human milk component change across lactation This chapter presents longitudinal trajectory analyses assessing whether maternal nutritional interventions influenced within-individual changes in human milk composition across successive postpartum visits. Unlike the cross-sectional analyses presented elsewhere in the supplement, these analyses focus on changes over time in milk components within the same motherinfant dyads. For each milk component, trajectories were constructed by transforming the raw concentration measurements into visit-to-visit differences, defined as the difference between a given visit and the immediately preceding visit within each mother. This approach isolates temporal changes in milk composition and evaluates whether the magnitude or direction of those changes differed by intervention arm. Baseline visits without a prior observation were excluded from the trajectory analyses. Trajectory-specific intervention effects were estimated using targeted maximum likelihood estimation (TMLE), with adjustment for the same prespecified baseline prognostic covariates used in the primary adjusted analyses. Outcomes were standardized prior to estimation to facilitate comparability across components with different measurement scales. Analyses were conducted separately by study and visit interval, and intervention arms were pooled where appropriate to improve statistical efficiency. Results are summarized using volcano plots for primary outcomes (macronutrients, micronutrients, and B-vitamins), secondary outcomes (HMOs and bioactive proteins), and tertiary outcomes (targeted metabolites). These plots display estimated intervention effects on visit-to-visit changes alongside corresponding statistical significance after false-discovery rate (FDR) correction, highlighting milk components for which supplementation was associated with altered temporal trajectories rather than static differences at a single visit. Accompanying tables provide full numerical results for trajectory effects, including adjusted estimates, confidence intervals, and multiplicity-adjusted p-values for both pooled intervention contrasts and combined-arm analyses. In addition, trajectory line plots visualize mean milk component concentrations over time by intervention arm for selected outcomes, linking the modeled trajectory effects to observed longitudinal patterns. These trajectory analyses are exploratory and should be interpreted cautiously. Power to detect trajectory-specific intervention effects is limited by the number of repeated measurements per participant and by sample size within individual studies and visit intervals. Accordingly, primary inference regarding intervention effects is based on cross-sectional adjusted analyses at prespecified visits, with trajectory analyses serving to contextualize those findings and to explore whether supplementation is associated with consistent, delayed, or cumulative changes in milk composition across early lactation. 9.1 Tables ## Warning in instance$preRenderHook(instance): It seems your data is too big for client-side ## DataTables. You may consider server-side processing: https://rstudio.github.io/DT/server.html ## Warning in instance$preRenderHook(instance): It seems your data is too big for client-side ## DataTables. You may consider server-side processing: https://rstudio.github.io/DT/server.html 9.2 Trajectory lineplots The final figures in this chapter visualize longitudinal trajectories of human milk components by intervention arm within each study. Line plots display mean milk component levels across successive visits, aggregated within biologically defined component categories (for example, macronutrients, B-vitamins, HMOs, amino acids, and other metabolite classes), and stratified by randomized intervention arm. For each study separately, milk component measurements were first aligned to study-specific visit schedules and harmonized across visits. Individual milk components were then grouped into predefined analytical categories. Within each study, visit, and intervention arm, component values were averaged across all available biomarkers within a category to produce category-level summaries. Plots are shown both on a standardized scale (z-scored within study and visit) to facilitate comparison of temporal patterns across categories with different units and variances, and on the original measurement scale to preserve interpretability of absolute concentrations. ## $p_misame_scaled ## ## $p_elicit_scaled ## ## $p_vital_scaled ## ## $p_misame_unscaled ## ## $p_misame_unscaled ## ## $p_vital_unscaled
